awd_titl_txt: Blinding speed: Effects of relative motion on visually guided pursuit
awd_abstract_narration: Ever photograph a moving object using a camera set at too slow a shutter speed?  If so, then you know that the resulting image may be low contrast and blurry.  Similar optical principles apply to biological visual systems. When the speed of retinal photoreceptors and/or neurons in the brain is not fast enough to overcome the relative velocity between the observer and the target, the visual image can become too blurred for the observer to recognize objects.  Humans rarely experience this effect because we move slowly, but many animals move quickly and suffer motion blur during pursuit of targets.  This project will investigate the visual and locomotory systems of fast-running, predatory tiger beetles that go blind while chasing prey and must stop briefly (tens of milliseconds) to re-localize the prey and then run again.  The basic question is why does the beetle run faster than its eyes and brain can process target images?  Dr. Gilbert will use a combination of 1) electrophysiological experiments on nerve cells at different levels in the beetle's visual system to test their response to moving targets, 2) behavioral studies of tethered beetles chasing computer generated, virtual reality images to quantify the effects of motion blur on pursuit tracking, and 3) computer modeling of the perception of the moving world viewed by a simulated beetle visual system to determine whether the beetle goes blind in all areas of the visual field or whether some running strategies may reduce blur in certain areas and allow continued tracking.  By investigating an extreme biological example of the effects of motion blur on a tracking system, Dr. Gilbert will discover design principles about the nature of all visual systems, as well as provide insight into the limits of man-made machine vision systems and possible strategies for overcoming deleterious effects of motion blur.  In terms of broader impacts related to education and nurturing of future scientists, the project will provide interdisciplinary training between engineering and biology for a post-doctoral fellow and undergraduate students.

por.por_cntn:
Visual cells in the retina take some time to respond to changes in light and send a signal to the brain. If images move too quickly in front of the eye, or an observer moves too quickly in a stationary environment, their visual cells cannot keep up with the changes in light intensity and the image becomes blurred and the contrast is washed out.   This phenomenon can affect all visual creatures, but we humans rarely notice because we move too slowly to experience such motion blur, unless we are riding on a machine. To understand how faster animals cope with degradation of their visual world, we used behavioral, optical and neurophysiological methods to study a predatory tiger beetle that runs so fast in pursuit of insect prey that it goes completely blind and must stop to re-localize its prey. During stops, when the image of the prey moves from the view of one visual cell to that of the neighboring cell, the beetle localizes it and begins running again after a lag of about 30 milliseconds (ms).

We determined that the stops during pursuit are due to motion blindness by varying the visual contrast of artificial prey in laboratory experiments. Images of low contrast prey blur more easily and the beetle chases in run-stop-run mode. But when the contrast of the prey is high (black against a white background) the beetle can chase it continuously. The visual position of the prey on the retina drives the angular velocity of the running beetle, again with a lag time of about 30 ms. In separate experiments using visual stimulation and recording the twitch of a beetle’s leg, we recorded the minimum time for a nervous signal to go from the eye to the leg was also about 30 ms. Thus, the beetle’s sensori-motor system during pursuit is performing about as fast as it can. The slow speed of the visual cells of the eye represent the bottleneck in the system that forces the beetle to stop during pursuit.

While running fast, the beetle is blind not only to its prey, but also to obstacles in its environment. These beetles typically live in flat environments, such as sandy areas, woodland paths, etc. From optical measurements we determined that the beetle has a region of higher visual acuity in its eye, as we do. But it differs from ours in that the high acuity region spreads horizontally across the eye and views the horizon, instead of just being aimed straight ahead as ours is. This horizontal “streak” of high acuity is adaptive for an animal that lives in a relatively flat world in which most of the interesting features will appear on the horizon. Their environment does contain vegetation, grass stems, small pebbles, etc. that could be obstacles in their path during pursuit of prey. If these are of low visual contrast, they will also blur out while the beetle is running. To ameliorate the possibility of crashing into an obstacle during pursuit, we determined that the beetle compensates with anatomical and behavioral  specializations of its two antennae. It holds them forward with the tips curved down and just above the substrate. The first seven segments of the antenna are relatively stiff, but the final downcurved four segments are very flexible. In laboratory experiments with obstacles of different heights, we determined that the flexible segments brush against an obstacle and bend back triggering a higher movement of the front leg on the next step to avoid or surmount the obstacle. Removal of the antennae causes the running beetles to crash into obstacles.

Thus, we have taken advantage of an animal that experiences an extreme case of motion blur and which is amenable to laboratory study. Birds and fish that move quickly are certainly blind to much of their environment. However, they are too large to study in the lab, whereas the tiger beetle is comfortable on a table top. We determined that one system, the sensori-motor system, may function close to optimally in terms of transmission speed, but that the visual cells of the eye are too slow. The animal compromises by stopping (fish and birds in pursuit of prey do not have that luxury) and has also evolved specializations in another sensory system, the antenna, to compensate for its visual limitations.

The project provided training for several young scientists including one woman, as well as a physician. They have all gone on to advance in STEM careers.
